items.content:
Spiders
Katia, Fred and Todd are talking about spiders.
Do you think spiders are scary? Or do you think they are cool, like Katia?

Click on the link to go to the conversation.
www.elllo.org
If you want to read the text while they are talking press: ON at Text View.

After that click on Start and do the exercise.
Remember your score for the work plan.

prompt.body: What did they try to do to the spider?
What was the spider trying to do?
How do they feel about spiders?

items.content:
Matt's pets
Matt speaks about his family and their pets.
Listen to the story and answer the questions.

Remember your score for your workplan.

content.body: Yes, two dogs and a cat.
Yes, two cats and a dog.

prompt.body: What kind of dogs does he train?
Does he ever see dogs after he trains them?

items.content:
Introduction
There are all kinds of texts, letters, articles, stories, advertisements and poems. You are going to read some examples of these texts in this reading section.

In these texts you'll read about different kinds of animals and pets.
By doing the exercises you'll be able to improve your reading skills.

New Words. Do you know what they mean?

  • ground hog
  • hare
  • tortoise
  • squirrel


Have fun reading!

Tips
Before you start reading:
Don't start reading straight away. First look at the title, the picture and highlighted words. These can help you understand what the text is about.

  • Read the introduction.
  • Read the questions before you start reading the text.
  • If you see multiple-choice questions, look at the options and try to see what the differences are.

While reading:
It will be very very difficult to understand everything you are going to read.
If you see a word you do not know, it is very important to ask yourself if this word is important to understand the text. If you understand the text without knowing the word, there is no need to use a dictionary. If the word is important to understand the text (and / or to answer questions) go ahead and use your dictionary! Just make sure you don't use the dictionary all the time!

Ground hog day
Read the text and do the exercise.
Remember your score for your work plan.

A ground hog is a small animal that digs and lives under the ground. It is also called the woodchuck. Ground hogs live in many parts of America. In the winter they hibernate like bears and some other animals.

There is a legend that says a few hundred years ago Europeans brought Ground Hog Day to America. They said that the ground hog wakes up from his hibernation on February 2. (February 2 is half way between winter and spring.) If he comes up from his hole and it is sunny, he will see his shadow and be frightened. If he sees his shadow, there will be 6 more weeks of winter weather. But if he comes up and the sky is cloudy, he will not see his shadow and will not be frightened. Then spring weather will come very soon.

Some people believe this legend and they watch the sky on February 2. Many people are happy if it is cloudy on that day. They think spring will come soon. But most people think it is just a fun legend.

What do you think?

Vocabulary
ground hog - bosmarmot
to hibernate (verb)- to sleep through the winter.
hibernation (noun)- comes from the verb 'to hibernate' (long sleep through the winter).
legend- old story that is told from parents to children, and children's children, and so on for many many years.
shadow- darkness made where the light can't go through (when the sun shines you can see the dark outline of your body on the ground).


Bron: ww.5minuteenglish.com

prompt.body: Another name for ground hog is woodchuck.
Ground hogs live under the ground.
A ground hog hibernates (=sleeps) during the winter.
The ground hog wakes up from his hibernation on February 3.
If a ground hog sees his shadow, there will be five more weeks of winter.

items.content:
The hare and the tortoise
The hare likes to brag.
He makes a bet with the tortoise.
He can run the fastest of course - so winning should be easy ...

Assignment

  • Ask a printed version of the worksheet "The Hare and the tortoise" from your teacher.
  • Download the story: The hare and the tortoise .
  • Fill in the worksheet.
  • Then give the worksheet to your teacher to check.


Tip
You can use www.macmillandictionary.com to find words you don't know.

The last 5 minutes of every lesson ...........

  • Have you filled in your workplan yet?
  • Write down in your notebook what went right and what was difficult.
  • Did you learn new words? If so, are they already in your notebook, to learn at home.
  • Continue with Duolingo.

• Learn chunks A of Animals and Pets at WRTS
  • Rehearse words A, B and C
  • Rehearse exercises you think you haven't done very well
